Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: Breaking through the taxonomic barrier of the fossil pollen record using bioimage informatics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The practice of identifying pollen has a large number of scientific applications and is used in fields as diverse as archaeology, biostratigraphy (the dating of rocks), and forensic science. Pollen and spores play a particularly important role in paleontology, because they form the most abundant and extensive record of plant diversity, dating back hundreds of millions of years. However, the most critical hypotheses in plant ecology and evolution (e.g. the assembly of plant communities, speciation and extinction) cannot be fully tested with pollen data due to the extreme difficulty of recognizing species from pollen and spore material. This project develops new methods to probe the shape and fine structural and textural properties of the grains using high-throughput, super-resolution structured illumination microscopy and automated image analysis in order to transform species identification from a subjective, by-eye procedure to a quantitative, computational practice. Since it is not known a priori which morphological features are phylogenetically meaningful, new machine learning techniques are being developed to model pollen images at multiple scales, identify aspects of shape and texture that are statistically informative, and infer their relation to the underlying phylogenetic structure.

The project has the ambitious long-term goal of creating a high-throughput system for analyzing pollen data that incorporates meaningful characterizations of pollen and spore morphology, provides testable hypotheses of biological affinity, and is open and available to the entire scientific community. This will allow researchers to break through the current taxonomic limitations of pollen identification and fundamentally change current practices in the discipline on many levels, from the basic task of identification and counting to the interpretation and use of these data in global climate-vegetation models. The project brings together a diverse, interdisciplinary team including international collaborators at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama and will train graduate and undergraduate students from multiple scientific disciplines and backgrounds in an emerging area of interdisciplinary research. A public outreach component is in development that will include a virtual microscopy web site using images generated by this research to introduce non-experts to the beauty, complexity, and relevance of pollen morphology. Additional information about this project can be found at: http://www.life.illinois.edu/punyasena

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pollen analysis has a large and varied number of uses, from dating the age of rock strata to forensic applications. Pollen and spores play a particularly important role in paleoecology and paleoclimatology, as they represent the most abundant and extensive data source on the history of plant diversity, dating back 470 million years. However, the biological affinities of the majority of pollen and spore morphospecies are unknown. This means that many critical hypotheses in plant ecology and evolution (e.g., community assembly, speciation, and extinction events) cannot be explicitly tested with pollen data. Our project addressed the long-standing problem of taxonomic uncertainty of fossil pollen identifications by demonstrating the degree to which machine learning and computer vision methods could consistently and accurately identify the taxonomy of pollen species.

 

Intellectual Merit. The project developed streamlined imaging protocols for two forms of optical superresolution microscopy: superresolution structured illumination microscopy (SR-SIM) and Airyscan confocal. Optical superresolution captures morphological features on and within the pollen wall that are below the diffraction limit of light (250 nm). These ?nanoscale? features are often critical to pollen classification and had previously only been studied using more destructive and labor-intensive electron microscopy. Using SR-SIM and Airyscan, we produced public image libraries for four large clades: the grass family Poaceae, the mallow subfamily Bombacoideae (Malvaceae), the legume tribe Amherstieae (Fabaceae), and the conifer genus Podocarpus (Podocarpaceae).

We experimented with deep learning methods, primarily convolutional neural nets (CNNs), in developing our image segmentation and classification models. We developed models that were robust to individualistic differences among images and were generalizable across image datasets. Most significantly, our models trained on modern vouchered herbarium samples could be applied to the classification of fossil specimens.

Our results demonstrate the utility of next-generation deep learning methods in addressing challenging visual biological classification problems. The results lay the foundations for a transformation of pollen and other microfossil identifications from a subjective, by-eye procedure to a reproducible, quantitative, computational practice with explicit measurements of identification certainty. The generalizability of our CNN models suggests that the remaining obstacle to large-scale automation of pollen identifications will be in the development of high-resolution image databases.

 

Broader Impacts. The project brought together a diverse, interdisciplinary team with expertise in pollen identification, high-resolution imaging, pattern analysis, computational modeling of shape and texture, and machine learning. The project engaged four graduate students, one postdoctoral researcher, and five undergraduates from Plant Biology/Integrative Biology at University of Illinois, a graduate student in Computer Science at the University of California Irvine, and a graduate and a undergraduate student in Mathematics at Florida State University.

The project set the ambitious long-term goal of creating a high-throughput system of analyzing pollen data that incorporates phylogenetically meaningful characterizations of pollen and spore morphology, provides testable hypotheses of taxonomic affinity, and is open and available to the entire scientific community. Our results establish the first steps toward that goal. We anticipate that wider dissemination of the developed tools, methods, and results will transform the way that pollen data are interpreted and analyzed, and allow the full exploitation of the information on biodiversity stored in the fossil pollen and spore record.
